content:
Congratulations on completing your adorable cat figurine! Pricing your artwork can be a challenging but important step in preparing for a craft fair. Here are some tips to help you determine a fair price for your earthenware sculptures:

1. **Calculate your costs:** Consider the cost of materials, including the clay, glazes, and any other supplies used. Don't forget to factor in the cost of your time, including the time spent on creating, firing, and refining your piece.
2. **Research the market:** Look at what similar pieces are selling for at craft fairs, online marketplaces, and local art galleries. This will give you an idea of what customers are willing to pay for similar work.
3. **Consider your skill level and experience:** As a beginner, you may need to price your work lower than an established artist. However, if you've invested significant time and effort into developing your skills, you may be able to command higher prices.
4. **Size and complexity matter:** Larger, more complex pieces typically require more time and materials, so they should be priced accordingly.
5. **Pricing strategy:** You can use one of two pricing strategies:
	* **Cost-plus pricing:** Add a markup to your total costs to determine the selling price.
	* **Value-based pricing:** Price your piece based on its perceived value to the customer, considering factors like uniqueness, craftsmanship, and emotional appeal.
6. **Round numbers and price anchoring:** Use round numbers (e.g., $20, $50, $100) to make your prices more appealing and memorable. You can also use price anchoring, where you display a higher "regular" price next to a lower "sale" price to make the latter seem more attractive.
7. **Be prepared to negotiate:** Some customers may try to negotiate the price, so be prepared to be flexible. However, don't be too quick to lower your prices, as this can devalue your work.
8. **Display and presentation:** Make sure your sculptures are well-displayed and presented in an attractive manner. This can help justify higher prices and make your work more appealing to customers.

For a small, intricate earthenware figurine like your cat, you might consider pricing it between $20 to $50, depending on the level of detail and the amount of time invested. If it's a one-of-a-kind piece or has unique features, you may be able to price it higher.

Remember to stay confident in your pricing and be prepared to explain the value and craftsmanship that goes into each piece. Good luck at the craft fair, and I hope your sculptures find new homes!
